snippet: A small community of “Westerners” — descendants of 19th-century settlers — is shrinking in Chichi Jima, as young people leave the isolated Japanese island, a 25-hour ferry ride from Tokyo.
abstract: Small community of Westerners, descendants of 19th-century settlers, is shrinking in Chichi Jima, as young people leave the isolated Japanese island that is a 25-hour ferry ride from Tokyo; about 2,000 people live there and over time, they have overwhelmed the descendants of the original settlers, known here as Obeikei, who are now estimated to number fewer than 200.
lead_paragraph: A small community of “Westerners” — descendants of 19th-century settlers — is shrinking in Chichi Jima, as young people leave the isolated Japanese island, a 25-hour ferry ride from Tokyo.

headline.seo: Fewer Westerners Remain on Remote Japanese Island
headline.main: A Western Outpost Shrinks on a Remote Island Now in Japanese Hands
headline.print_headline: A Western Outpost Shrinks on a Remote Island Now in Japanese Hands
